node.text:
We must change and care for our planet.
And that change starts with education.
Let’s #LearnForOurPlanet to build a better future for all! 🌍
.
.
.
.
#Education #EducationForSustainableDevelopment #ESD #ClimateAction #ActOnClimate #ParisAgreement #ClimateChange #GlobalGoals #TogetherForOurPlanet #SustainableDevelopment #ActNow #SustainableDevelopmentGoals #SDGs #UNESCO #ClimateStrike #ChangingMindsNotTheClimate #GlobalWarming

node.text:
Culture and heritage are not a mere commodity.

As ethnic motifs become trendy, the world’s fast growing fashion market must respect the rights and interests of indigenous communities. 

Ahead of Thursday's #WorldArtDay, read the @unescocourier and learn more via link BIO 👆
.
.
.
.
#ShareCulture #Culture #IndigenousPeoples #WeAreIndigenous #UNESCO #UNSCOCourier

node.text:
the world witnessed the destruction of the 2 standing Bamiyan Buddhas in Afghanistan, tragically reducing history and cultural heritage of the world to rubble. 

The empty niches of the giant Buddhas in the Bamiyan Valley of Afghanistan are a perpetual reminder of our duty to protect cultural heritage, and what future generations stand to lose if we do not. 

Today, the area is considered by UNESCO a World Heritage Site in Danger. 
.
.
.
.
#UNESCO #ProtectHeritage #ShareOurHeritage #ShareCulture

.

node.text:
It’s the Smurfs and they have an important message to share...

New research from @UNESCO’s latest report on marine World Heritage sites show they play a crucial role in mitigating Climate Change and meeting Paris Agreement targets.

The 50 marine sites on UNESCO's World Heritage List comprise at least 21% of the global area of blue carbon ecosystems and 15% of global blue carbon assets - carbon stores that are equivalent to about 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions in 2018.

Their protection plays a central role in storing carbon from the atmosphere. But degradation of these ecosystem can also release billions of tons of greenhouse gases.
.
.
.
.
#WorldHeritage #ClimateChange #ParisAgreement #UNESCO #ActNow

node.text:
Among the hardest hit are travel and tourism and culture.

The disruption of many intangible cultural practices will have heavy consequences for communities and those working in the performing arts and traditional crafts for years. 

Read the full story via the @unescocourier link in bio 👆
.
.
.
.
#UNESCO #UNESCOCourier #COVID19 #Culture #Tourism #RestartTourism #ShareCulture #UNESCO #UNESCOCourier #ShareOurHeritage

node.text:
This week marked the 76th anniversary of the liberation of the concentration and extermination camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau by Soviet troops.

The soldiers found around seven thousand emaciated detainees, many of whom perished in the following days. They saw the corpses of the sickest and weakest prisoners, executed after the Nazis forced the majority of the prisoners still alive to take part in a “death march” towards the west. They also discovered traces of the merciless system that the Nazis put in place, and the efforts they made to disguise it: destroyed files, damaged photographs and the remaining gas chambers.

Auschwitz-Birkenau was the most murderous killing centre and the largest concentration camp established by Nazi Germany during the Holocaust. It was here that over 1.1 million Jews and tens of thousands of Roma, Poles, Soviet prisoners-of-war and other persecuted populations lost their lives.

Today, as hateful voices continue to rise, denying or distorting the implacable reality of these facts, we have a universal responsibility to remember each and every individual whom the Nazis sought to erase from the face of the earth. We must remember the communities and cultures that were destroyed; we must care for historic sites; we must protect and preserve against attempts to spread the ideas that led to the genocide of Jewish people and other Nazi crimes, and that threaten the human rights of all.

The International Day of Commemoration in Memory of the Victims of the Holocaust is a time to mourn those who disappeared and to reflect upon the choices of the individuals and governments that allowed this genocide to unfold. It is also a call for vigilance and for action, to address the root causes of hatred and prevent future atrocities from happening.

.
.
.
.
#HolocaustRemembrance #HolocaustRemembranceDay #Auschwitz76 #Holocaust #HolocaustEducation
#Education #Shoah #ShoahMemorial #HolocaustMemorialDay #HolocaustMemorial #WeRemember #History #NeverForget #UNESCO #NeverAgain

.

.

"Ignorance, allied with power, is the most ferocious enemy justice can have". 
Remembering today American novelist, dramatist and civil rights activist James Baldwin, born #OnThisDay in 1924.

Baldwin wrote about race, sexuality and class in the United States and became a leading figure in the fight for civil rights. To this day, his work continues to inspire people across the world.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Happy International Day of Friendship! Today, 30 July is an opportunity to remember the ties that bind us together, regardless of race, religion, gender, sexual orientation or borders.

Now more than ever, let's cultivate solidarity as a single human family on our one and only planet. Let's celebrate today and every day friendship's power to build bridges between peoples & cultures.

And you? Do you believe in friendship's power to craft a better world for all?

Like and comment if you do.

node.text:
Meet the iconic Bengal tiger - the most populous but endangered tiger subspecies in the world.

These tigers can be found in the mangroves of the Sundarbans!
The Sundarbans forests, the largest mangrove forests worldwide, are known for their wide range of fauna, including 260 bird species, the Bengal tiger and other threatened species. It is the only mangrove forest in the world this tiger subspecies calls its home.

The Sundarbans lies on the delta of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Meghna rivers on the Bay of Bengal. It is adjacent to the border of India’s Sundarbans World Heritage site inscribed in 1987.

However, the impacts of climate change chasing rising sea levels are increasingly threatening the Sundarbans and the Bengal tiger. In general, tigers are a vital link in maintaining the rich diversity of nature.

UNESCO is committed to manage the property to retain the biodiversity, it’s unique ecosystems and aesthetic values. The biosphere reserve is also working with the local community to create a peaceful co-existence between humans & tigers. When tigers are protected, we save so much more.

The ecosystems of the Sundarbans supply both nature and people with fresh water, food, and health. If we want a future, we must protect Earth's biodiversity. The time to act is now.

Photo credit: : Shutterstock// konmesa 📸
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#TigerDay #InternationalTigerDay #unesco #mangrove #mangroves #forest #bengal #bengaltiger #tiger #india #bangladesh #biodiversity #ecosystems #ecosystem #nature #biospherereserve #biosphere #ForNature #UNESCO #WorldHeritage #GlobalGoals

node.text:
Check out the latest incriptions on the World Heritage List! 🤗🤗🤗 The World Heritage Committee today added four sites to UNESCO’s World Heritage List and one extension to an existing transnational natural site in Europe. 

The new cultural sites are located in Italy, Slovenia, the Russian Federation and the United Kingdom.  The natural site inscribed today is Ivindo National Park in Gabon. The World Heritage Committee also approved an extension to the existing World Heritage site of Ancient and Primeval Beech Forests of the Carpathians and Other Regions of Europe.

These additions were made during the extended 44th session of the World Heritage Committee held online and chaired from Fuzhou (China), which is examining nominations from both 2020 and 2021.

Check the link in bio for more details on all the new sites!
.
.
.
#WorldHeritage # #Culture #Heritage #ProtectHeritage #ShareCulture #44whc #unesco #Italy #Russia #Slovenia #UK #Gabon #UnitedKingdom

node.text:
The UNESCO Youth Eyes👁‍🗨 on the #UNESCOSilkRoads photo contest is now underway!

This year we call on the creativity of youth to capture the beauty of the textiles and clothing produced and worn along the Silk Roads. 

Find inspiration in the festivals and celebrations along these rich ancient routes, where you will find dances with vibrant clothing like those in
‘The First Sama Dance’ taken by Nilofar Niekpor. It was selected among the best photos of the 2019 Youth Eyes on the Silk Roads Photo Contest.

Deadline is 24 August! To find out more and submit your photos, check the link in bio.
.
.
.
.
📷 Photo credit: Nilofar Niekpor (@nilofarniekpor) / UNESCO Youth Eyes on the Silk Roads
.
.

node.text:
These are the new inscriptions on UNESCO's World Heritage List! 😊😊😊 The World Heritage Committee today added 13 cultural sites to the List and one extension to an existing cultural site in Mexico. The new sites are the following: 

India, Dholavira: A Harappan City, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Cultural Landscape of Hawraman/Uramanat.

Japan, Jomon Prehistoric Sites in Northern Japan.

Roșia Montană Mining Landscape (Romania), simultaneously inscribed on the List of World Heritage in Danger pending the removal of threats to its integrity posed by possible extractive activities.

Jordan, As-Salt - The Place of Tolerance and Urban Hospitality.

Côte d'Ivoire, Sudanese style mosques in northern Côte d’Ivoire.

France, Nice, Winter Resort Town of the Riviera 

Brazil, Sítio Roberto Burle Marx.

Peru, Chankillo Archaeoastronomical Complex, Uruguay, The work of engineer Eladio Dieste: Church of Atlántida.

Chile, Settlement and Artificial Mummification of the Chinchorro Culture in the Arica and Parinacota Region.

Mexico, Franciscan Ensemble of the Monastery and Cathedral of Our Lady of the Assumption of Tlaxcala [extension of “Earliest 16th-Century Monasteries on the Slopes of Popocatepetl”, inscribed in 1994].

Germany / Netherlands, Frontiers of the Roman Empire – The Lower German Limes.

Germany, ShUM Sites of Speyer, Worms and Mainz.

These additions were made during the extended 44th session of the World Heritage Committee held online and chaired from Fuzhou (China), which is examining nominations from both 2020 and 2021. The inscription of sites on UNESCO’s World Heritage List is scheduled to continue through 28 July.

Check the link in bio for more details on all the new sites!
.
.
.
#WorldHeritage #Japan #Netherlands #CotedIvoire #Germany #Mexico #Peru #Chile #Uruguay #Romania #Iran #India #France #Jordan #Brazil #Culture #Heritage #ProtectHeritage #ShareCulture #44whc #unesco

node.text:
Have you ever seen bumblebees buzzing around?

Attracted by the colour and smell of flowers, these insects are actually looking for food.  By involuntarily transporting pollen from one flower to another they ensure the pollination of many plants and are therefore essential to the preservation of our planet’s flora.

The @bumblebeeconservationtrust is a #UnescoGreenCitizens project that takes into account the importance of these small creatures and acts #ForNature.

Discover and support this citizen-led project. Link in bio 💚
.
.
.
.
#GlobalGoals #ActNow #ForNature #BeatPollution #ClimateAction #SustainableDevelopment #Biodiversity #GenerationRestauration #ActNow #Biodiversity

node.text:
Seven new sites have been added to UNESCO’s World Heritage List! 😃😃😃 Four of the sites have been inscribed for their natural attributed: Amami-Oshima Island, Tokunoshima Island, northern part of Okinawa Island, and Iriomote Island (Japan), Getbol, Korean Tidal Flats (Republic of Korea), Kaeng Krachan Forest Complex (Thailand) and Colchic Rainforests and Wetlands (Georgia). Three were listed for their cultural properties, among them one transnational site: Arslantepe Mound (Turkey), Extension of Defence Lines of Amsterdam, henceforth to be known as Dutch Water Defence Lines (Netherlands) and the transnational site of Colonies of Benevolence (Belgium and Netherlands). The inscriptions of new sites will continue over the coming days. Stay tuned for more!

.
.
.
#WorldHeritage #Japan #RepublicOfKorea #Thailand #Georgia #Turkey #Netherlands #Belgium #Culture #Heritage #ProtectHeritage #ShareCulture #44whc #unesco

node.text:
26 July is International Day for the Conservation of the Mangrove Ecosystem. Perhaps you didn't know this, but mangroves are rare, spectacular and prolific ecosystems on the boundary between land and sea.

These extraordinary ecosystems contribute to the wellbeing, food security, and protection of coastal communities worldwide. They support a rich biodiversity and provide a valuable nursery habitat for fish and crustaceans. Mangroves also act as a form of natural coastal defense against storm surges, tsunamis, rising sea levels and erosion. Their soils are highly effective carbon sinks, sequestering vast amounts of carbon.

Yet mangroves are disappearing three to five times faster than overall global forest losses, with serious ecological and socio-economic impacts. Current estimates indicate that mangrove coverage has been divided by two in the past 40 years.

UNESCO is engaged deeply in supporting the conservation of mangroves, while advancing the sustainable development of their local communities. The inclusion of mangroves in Biosphere Reserves, World Heritage sites and UNESCO Global Geoparks contributes to improving the knowledge, management and conservation of mangrove ecosystems throughout the world.

The International Day for the Conservation of the Mangrove Ecosystem, adopted by the General Conference of UNESCO in 2015, aims to raise awareness of the importance of mangrove ecosystems as “a unique, special and vulnerable ecosystem" and to promote solutions for their sustainable management, conservation and uses.

#MangroveDay #ForNature #Ecosystem #MakeOurPlanetGreatAgain #ClimateChange #GlobalGoals #SustainableDevelopment #Nature #SDGs #BiosphereReserves #Earth #ClimateAction #ActOnClimate

node.text:
"I kept studying… and just like Malala, who fought for her life and her right to education, we as a woman must keep fighting" - María Castro Lux, participant UNESCO-MALALA Centers.

For María Castro Lux, a young mother of three children, being part of one of the UNESCO-Malala-Mineduc Centers has meant learning to value her self-esteem, undertake new initiatives and, become a fighter.

Education has positive effects on the lives of women such as María, who despite getting married at an early age and, having to interrupt her studies of elementary school, is currently studying her last year of junior high school. María, a proud mother of two girls and a small boy, is one of the female leaders of the UNESCO-Malala Center located in Santa María Chiquimula.

Like Maria, more than 900 girls and young indigenous women have participated in the UNESCO-Malala-Mineduc Centers over the past three years. Thanks to these centers, women are given the opportunity to have an education for a better future.
.
.
.
.
Photo credit: ©️Armando Velázquez
.
.
#MalalaCenters #Guatemala #Malala #Mineduc #Future #Education #LeaveNoOneBehind #Women #RightToEducation.
